G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this negligence action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, because the amount in controversy is less than $50,000 and the events giving rise to this action occurred within Worcester County.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the acts and omissions complained of occurred in Worcester, Massachusetts.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to maintain the premises, including the sidewalk under her control, in a condition reasonably safe for lawful visitors and foreseeable users.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolishes the common-law distinction between invitees and licensees in Massachusetts and adopts a general duty of reasonable care owed by occupiers of land to lawful visitors. While the provided excerpt is only a concurrence focusing on trespassers, the majority opinion in Mounsey clearly holds that an occupier must exercise reasonable care to maintain premises (including areas under their control) in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors and foreseeable users. The concurrence does not contradict that core holding.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: We therefore hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are abolished in this Commonwealth. The duty owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors is to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury, the probable seriousness of such injury, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7 15.proposition: Defendant also had a duty, pursuant to G.L. c. 84, § 15, to exercise due care in maintaining a public way adjacent to property under her control so as not to create or permit unsafe conditions caused by snow and ice.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner must act as a reasonable person under all circumstances to prevent injury from foreseeable risks.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that Massachusetts premises liability for snow and ice is governed by the same general standard of reasonable care as for other hazards, and it articulates that duty in terms of acting as a reasonable person under all the circumstances, considering likelihood and seriousness of injury and the burden of avoiding the risk. That directly matches the claimed proposition about a property owner’s duty to prevent injury from foreseeable risks. The case abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction precisely in favor of this general reasonable-person, foreseeability-based standard.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 169 (1980)… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner must act as a reasonable person under all circumstances to prevent injury from foreseeable risks.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that the duty owed by a property owner to lawful visitors is one of reasonable care in the circumstances, which is substantively the same as acting as a reasonable person under all the circumstances to prevent foreseeable injury. While the case then narrows liability in the specific context of natural accumulations of snow and ice, it affirms the general Massachusetts rule of reasonable care for property owners. Thus, it supports the broad proposition about the standard of care, though the holding applies a specific limitation in snow-and-ice cases.
Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The duty owed by a property owner to someone lawfully on the owner’s premises is one of reasonable care in the circumstances. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707-708 (1973). In our most recent decision addressing an owner’s duty with regard to snow and ice, we made clear that this duty is not violated by a failure to remove a natural accumulation of snow or ice.”

Jasko v. Waltham, 398 Mass. 230 (1986).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner must act as a reasonable person under all circumstances to prevent injury from foreseeable risks.
Jasko v. Waltham, 398 Mass. 230 (1986).support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a criminal case about rape and drugging for unlawful sexual intercourse. It does not deal with premises liability, duties of property owners, or the standard of reasonable care to prevent injury from foreseeable risks. Nothing in the holding or reasoning articulates or applies a rule about a property owner’s duty under Massachusetts tort law, so it cannot be authority for the stated proposition.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: The Defendant’s failure to remove or treat the ice constitutes a breach of duty recognized under Massachusetts common law of premises liability, including but not limited to Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013), which holds that liability arises when a property owner fails to act reasonably in light of foreseeable harm.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses a landowner’s common-law duty of reasonable care in Massachusetts premises liability and holds that this duty includes an obligation to remedy dangerous conditions, even if open and obvious, where the landowner can and should anticipate that lawful entrants will encounter the danger and be harmed. Although the facts involve a trampoline and pool rather than ice, the court expressly relies on Papadopoulos (a snow-and-ice case) and reiterates that liability can arise when a property owner fails to act reasonably in light of foreseeable harm. Thus, it supports the general duty/foreseeability principle cited, even if not the specific ice scenario.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg….”}

O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (.proposition: Plaintiff’s fall and resulting injuries were the direct and proximate result of Defendant’s breach of duty.
O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (.support_reasoning: The case does not support the proposition that the plaintiff’s fall and injuries were the direct and proximate result of the defendant’s breach of duty. Instead, the court holds that because the danger of diving into the shallow end was open and obvious, the defendants owed no duty to warn the plaintiff; without a duty, there can be no breach or proximate causation attributable to the defendants. The opinion is authority for a no-duty, no-liability outcome, not for establishing proximate cause from a defendant’s breach.
O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201 (.relevant_excerpt: “Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury… We conclude that, because the danger of diving into the shallow end of a swimming pool is open and obvious to a person of average intelligence, the defendants had no duty to warn the plaintiff of this danger as a matter of law and, therefore, they could not be found liable for his injuries.”

Mass. G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff was lawfully on the premises and did not assume the risk of the icy condition or act with contributory negligence.

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Because Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries, she is liable at common law.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: The opinion rejects imposing common-law negligence liability on the defendant social host in these circumstances, holding that no duty existed because the host neither served nor controlled the liquor consumed by the intoxicated guest. The court discusses negligence elements (including duty and causation) but concludes there is no common-law duty and therefore no liability, even though the guest’s intoxication caused the plaintiff’s injuries. Thus, the case does not stand for the proposition that a defendant whose negligence is a substantial factor is liable at common law; instead it denies liability here.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: "Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence... meaning that the plaintiff has the burden of proving each and every element of that claim: duty, breach of duty (or, the element of negligence), causation (actual and proximate) and damages... Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort."

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837 (1987)
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: Because Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries, she is liable at common law.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The excerpt concerns duty and proximate cause in a premises-liability context and concludes there is no duty to warn of the obvious risk of injury from another vehicle at a self-service gas station. It does not state that a defendant whose negligence is a substantial factor is liable; instead, it finds no actionable negligence or proximate cause on these facts. Thus, it does not support the proposition that Defendant’s negligence being a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries makes her liable at common law.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The question is whether, as a matter of law, Arco’s failure to erect a sign warning customers to be on guard against other vehicles did not unreasonably increase the risk of injury caused by the improper operation of other vehicles on the premises. I agree with the court that the evidence did not present a jury question.… In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑ and post‑judgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
